problem_text:
4.34. Let v be a group word, and let Kv be the class of groups G such that there exists a positive integer n = n(G) such that each element of the verbal subgroup vG can be represented as a product of n values of the word v on the group G.
a) For which v do all finitely generated soluble groups belong to the class Kv?
b) Does the word v(x, y) = x−1y−1xy satisfy this condition?
M. I. Kargapolov
